APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on motion [4th December, 1957].

    Question again proposed, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

10.07 a.m.

    Mr Seah Peng Chuan (Kampong Kapor): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. the Financial Secretary in his budget speech on 4th December, said (column 2830 of the Hansard):

    "... it is possible that the actual deficit would be of the order of $8 million...".

    It is possible that the actual deficit in 1958 will be of the order of $8 million, and to meet the deficit, it is proposed to increase, among other things, the duty on petrol and to make a slight increase in the special tax on heavy oil engine vehicles.

    Sir, I disagree most strongly with the Financial Secretary when he said that the imposition of the new rate on petrol is unlikely to cause any hardship to Singapore. It is quite possible, Sir, that in the near future, this increase in the price of petrol will be passed on to those who have to use public transport. Nor have the owners of private cars been let off lightly. Sir, car owners in the higher income group may be able to take the increase of 20 cents a gallon on petrol, they can afford it. But for those who find it necessary or convenient to own a car for a number of good reasons, this increase will result, when they come to balance their monthly budgets, in having to rob Peter to pay Paul.

    Looking closely at the picture, Sir, one cannot help coming to the conclusion that it is those who can least afford it who will be the most hard hit by this increase of 20 cents a gallon on petrol. For example, Sir, take a clerk who owns a car, draws $300 a month salary, and uses 1½ gallons of petrol a day. This means that the increased charge to him will be 30 cents. This clerk who owns a car conveys neighbours who work near his office or in the same office. They pay him, on mutual agreement, $10 per man, which means that each of them will have to pay an addition of $2 per head. This is what I do not like, Sir.

Column: 2896



    Another example is a taxi. Owners of taxis work on day and night shifts. The majority of them use five gallons of petrol per shift. An increase of 20 cents in the price of petrol will mean an addition of one dollar to the cost. As taxi drivers now earn at the rate of $5 per shift, this will mean that they will lose a dollar, thus reducing their actual earning to only $4. How can they live on $4 a day at the present time?

    Sir, instead of imposing an additional tax on petrol to meet part of the deficit of $8 million, the Government should concentrate its energy on encouraging the establishment of industries here by foreign investors, so that more employment will be available to local citizens. With more employment, more money will be in circulation. Instead, we are told by the Financial Secretary (column 2843), "Money is tighter." Sir, it is obvious that foreign investors can only be induced to come here to set up industries if the Government is in a position to assure them that the business and political climates here are healthy for their enterprises. If such conditions are not forthcoming in 1958, I am afraid there may be even a larger deficit when the Financial Secretary makes his next budget speech. Additional means of taxation may then have to be found to meet the deficit and probably it will again be those who can least afford it who will have to foot the bill.

    Sir, another point on industry. The Government concentrates on having more industry in Singapore, but the industries have to pay company tax or income tax at the rate of 30 per cent. And we have export tax and import tax.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): There is no import tax.

    Mr Seah Peng Chuan: We must bear these in mind. On big industries, Sir, the Hon. the Minister for Commerce and Industry says, 'Oh, we have a few of these industries breaking down, but we have small industries coming up.' Sir, one must realise that if a big industry closes down we may have unemployment of 300 persons. The small industries come up, and two or three of

Column: 2897

them may employ only about 100 people. So the balance of 200 persons are still unemployed. The Minister for Labour and Welfare is therefore not seeing things quite clearly. Also each unemployed man may be supporting a wife and child. I take the family to be a small one. So, 200 unemployed each with a family of a wife and child - an addition of two - will mean another 400 unemployed, making the total 600 instead of only 200. Sir, this is what I expect the Minister for Labour and Welfare should look into.

    Thirdly, Sir, income tax. An increase in taxation may be coming up. When the 1958 budget comes up, the Financial Secretary will say, 'We are still in deficit. We have no money now. So we are trying to find some way to meet the deficit.' That means more tax will be coming up for the wage-earner. We are now not taxing those earning $3,000 a year but the Government may think, 'Ah, we must do something to get some money by fixing up a minimum of $25 income tax on $3,000.' Who is going to suffer in the end? It is the lower income group.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I come now to the Financial Secretary's remarks on Malayanisation. He said (column 2824):

    "... it is likely that actual expenditure in 1957 will amount to about $242 million. It should be noted, however, that this total includes a sum of $9 million in respect of compensation under the Malayanisation Scheme."

    Very good, Sir, I have no quarrel with the principle of Malayanisation. In fact I am all in favour of it. I voted for it. But what I do not like about one aspect of the operation of the Malayanisation Scheme is that when certain expatriate officers are upgraded they take the opportunity shortly thereafter to retire and thereby receive higher Malayanisation benefits. I have heard of certain senior police officers who, while on leave abroad 8,000 miles away from Singapore, were promoted to higher ranks. They came back from leave to fill their higher appointments for just a few

Column: 2898

months and thereafter elected to retire under the Malayanisation scheme with larger retirement sums. This business of being here today and there tomorrow should be stopped.

    Sir, the opposite Government Benches must realise that the amount we have for payment under the Malayanisation scheme comes out of public money, not from ourselves. We must look into this carefully and not allow expatriates to return from their leave after being promoted from grade one to special grade, and then to retire. Otherwise where are we to get the money to pay them? It might cost more than $9 million, the figure stated in the Estimates. Sir, I would like the Government to look into this matter. We must stop the practice.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. the Financial Secretary in his last speech as an ex-officio Member of this Assembly has taken great pains in supporting his arguments for increased expenditure and consequent increased taxation. He has also drawn a gloomy picture for the future. Sir, not only he but his predecessors have from time to time drawn such pictures. I do think the picture for the future is gloomy when one looks at the appalling expenditure. Sir, be has raised matters in his speech with regard to stability and so on. I would like to touch on the speech he made the other day.

    Sir, the backbone of our income is the entrepot trade. Now nearly 150 years old, Singapore, what it is today, is built on entrepot trade. This life-blood we can still preserve if we try but there are conditions to keep this entrepot trade. First, Sir, is economic stability. Now, Sir, economic stability depends on political stability. An unstable government can never inspire confidence in the minds of the public, especially the investor, and unless there is a stable government, of the elected majority - I wonder why the Nominated Member Mr Thomas should laugh at this - this is an acknowledged

Column: 2899

fact which I can prove; and can anyone challenge this fact, that unless there is a stable government with an elected majority of the people, the government is not stable? Sir, I will deal more with this subject a little later.

    Sir, entrepot trade requires low handing charges. Handling charges should be the lowest to preserve and compete with neighbouring countries in selling or transhipping your goods, either imports or exports, from this territory. Now when I say handling charges it means lorry and boat hire, insurance, overhead charges, profits and so on, plus cheap labour. Sir, another condition to preserve this state is a free trade policy. We have heard time and time again wild talk of import duties or expectation of import duties, and of luxury taxation (of course dead now, I hope). Such talk keeps the mind of the public in a very uncertain state. There is a fear and trade will not settle down at its own proper level. If you want to preserve the entrepot trade, free trade policy should go on as it is now.

    The fourth thing is capital and labour. Sir, we should not forget that the reason why Singapore, originally a fishing village, is today a prosperous city is due to its entrepot trade. In the first instance, capital was brought by the British merchants. But capital could not do anything without labour, and labour was brought from India and China. Capital and labour worked hand in hand and therefore we now see a prosperous place. In other words, Sir, capital and labour, in the peculiar position of Singapore, is inter-dependent. I have said this previously and I repeat it again. Without capital, labour cannot exist. Capital can always flow in a favourable climate. Therefore, in a place like this, we should see that the capital is there and that labour is cooperating with capital.

    Sir, let me say this. When I said that in the first instance the British brought the capital, I should also say that they have taken back to England many, many times more of what they brought into Singapore - through dividends, salaries,

Column: 2900

pensions, banking, insurance, shipping, etc.

    Sir, a condition to preserve a state of racial and class harmony demands that preaching or saying anything which can create this racial or class hatred will destroy the economy of this city. Can we get capital from abroad to come to this city if we have wild talk which does more harm than good? We do know that we want capital. No country can do without foreign capital. That is the position today in Asia.

    Let us, Sir, depend on our sound commonsense. Many people have brought in a lot of "isms", possibly all from foreign countries. Now, Sir, Singapore being a small city, can we not form a policy taking the best of the two blocs for our economic purpose? I think the politicians should refrain from talking wild slogans unnecessarily, which will ultimately harm the masses - and our population is fast growing with plenty of unemployment.

    Sir, another factor towards maintaining our entrepot trade is a low cost of living. Can we not reduce our cost of living? Can we not formulate our policy that our cost of living comes down? Means have to be devised. As it stands today, the cost of living is going higher and higher.

    Sir, the next thing is industry, after entrepot trade. Many a time, politicians on the Government side have talked about the development of industry and bringing in capital from foreign countries to develop industry here. Sir, this kind of bluff serves no purpose whatsoever. It might keep people busy for a short time but these false hopes will only raise or create more unemployment and unrest.

    Now, Sir, how can industry survive unless these conditions are fulfilled? - capital is necessary; there should be cheap labour as in competing countries; a low cost of living so that the worker can remain contented; a vast hinterland for markets for our goods; political stability which can satisfy the investor that his capital is safe; cheap power to reduce our cost of production; low taxation; and raw material of our

Column: 2901

own (but this can be imported if the other factors are present).

    Let me say here and now, Sir, it is on these factors only that large industries can exist, and all the confusing and irresponsible talk will only cause more harm than good. Have we these conditions here? I challenge anyone to say that we have. They are not existing at all.

    Now, Sir, take for granted that someone starts a factory. What are you going to do with the goods produced at high cost? Can you sell them? If you cannot, then that industry has to close down. Then the argument starts: why not impose import duties to help this industry? Yes, you can help in that way, but the reason against it is this - that you are preventing your own Singaporeans from buying cheaper goods manufactured elsewhere in preference to his own goods, to meet his immediate needs. Another thing. Sir - if you have import duty to preserve such an industry, then you are selling your manufactured goods to your own people at a very high price. The result will be this, that you will have to increase wages and salaries. It leads you nowhere.

    Sir, our population is growing. What is the solution then? The only solution in the circumstances as we are faced today is to develop cottage and small-scale industries of which I spoke also at the last budget sitting. We should keep the families - wives and children - busy. The creation of these industries only is not sufficient - what is also very necessary is to foster them with loans, advances, marketing, etc.

    Now, Sir, people are blind to these and other factors when they talk of import duties. Those countries having import duties are already large with vast populations, and they do not depend on entrepot trade only. We are not in that position; we in this small territory are in a very peculiar position.

    Sir, economic stability is very essential and I said that it depends on political stability which can bring confidence to the investor, businessman and worker.

Column: 2902

What have we seen since this present Government came into power?-strikes, lock-outs, unrest, arrests, etc. Can this bring any confidence or stability to the public mind? We are not better off even today. We are in the same position. Government can always avoid strikes by looking into the matter immediately. If a strike takes place and is settled, it leaves a bad taste in both the mouth of the employer and the employee. Settlement should be made immediately, before a strike develops. Sir, the masses should also understand that they should not be misled by the wrong people. After all, they will be hitting themselves by this process.

    Sir, in the short period of the Coalition Government we have had two commissions of corruption appointed. Can they bring stability to the minds of the public?

    Coming to expenditure, Sir, there should be very rigid control of expenditure, both capital and administrative. Cut down extravagant expenditure, banquets and unnecessary travelling, and cut our coat according to our stature.

    Sir, one can compare our expenditure and income with those of the Federation, our neighbour. The Federation has a population four times bigger than Singapore. The Federation has thousands of miles of territories to administer. They have an Emergency too. If you compare it with our 220 odd square miles, you will see that our expenditure is definitely very high.

    Sir, as an illustration I might mention conferences. In previous years, Sir, Singapore was more politically advanced than the Federation. When we were invited to conferences, the Federation used to be satisfied either with briefing us or the United Kingdom chief of the delegation, and thus avoid expenditure. Can we not do this now wherever possible? After all we are a Colony still and we are in a secondary position with no vote.

    Sir, our cost of administration is the highest compared with that of any other Asian territory. Why? Yes, our

Column: 2903

standard of living is high, but in comparison the administration cost is too high, and that should be cut down wherever possible.

    Sir, coming to taxation, the Hon. the Financial Secretary has said that the financial position is sound. If so, why this additional taxation? The increase in tax on petrol and diesel oil engine vehicles will add to the difficulties and hardships of the masses mostly, as taxis, lorries, buses and so on will have to put up their fares. Who will be the losers? It is the masses. They will have to bear the extra cost, they will have to foot the bill. Besides, it will harm our entrepot trade too. Your lighterage and lorry charges will go up higher. You are making it more difficult for the entrepot trade because of this higher cost.

    To the Government, a fraction means nothing. I say a fraction, in relation to our 1½ million population, is very much. Sir, I might quote here a part of an editorial of the Singapore Standard:

    "When a political party comes into power, it wishes to experiment with its political theories, and in the course of such experiments the public are made to foot the bill, however unjustified that may be. The Government must remember that Singapore must be able to earn enough to meet its expenditure, since it is not a producing territory. Therefore, political experiments must not destroy world confidence in this entrepot, thereby affecting its trade and prosperity. The most capable of Financial Secretaries cannot perform miracles if the Government's political experiments were to drive away trade and kill the sources of revenue."

    Mr Speaker: Will the hon. Member give the date of issue of the newspaper?

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Thursday, 5th December.

    Now, Sir, this view is shared by thousands of people in Singapore. God alone can help if a recession in trade and a slump comes, as the Hon. the Financial Secretary has made a forecast of it. The best thing is to spend as little as possible. No doubt essentials like education and health should be fully supported but capital costs certainly can be reduced. Sir, compare the population of two or three years back with that of today. It is not so

Column: 2904

high and yet your expenditure has gone so high.

    Last thing, Sir - in the Estimates I have not seen any contributions to the Chinese Y.M.C.A., the Ramakrishna Mission, Sultan Mosque and the Young Men's Muslim Association, even though I understand the Financial Secretary received requests for help. I will not take up the Assembly's time on this; I will take up the matter at the Committee stage.

    Sir, in the end I must only say this, that the Coalition Government has failed, and failed miserably.

10.42 a.m.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, once again we meet in this House to debate the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill, that is the Estimates for next year. I consider that this work is more or less routine and nothing else. Every year at the end of November we come here and are asked to approve the Budget produced by the Government. Whatever amendments moved by the Opposition will serve no purpose. I have this morning received about 60 amendments to the Budget, Sir, but I doubt how many of them, or any at all, will go through. It is most unlikely because every time when a vote is put to the House, the Government has the majority, with the support of the ex-officios and Nominated Assemblymen. I may then, Sir, call elected Members of the Opposition as rubber stamps and nothing else. We come here just to put our signatures to the Budget because we are part and parcel of that Budget as well. We are partly responsible for its approval.

    Sir, last year the Hon. the Financial Secretary presented us with Estimates which showed a deficit of $18.7 million. What is the result of that deficit of $18.7 million, Sir? May I quote column 2824 of the Financial Secretary's speech:

    "Turning now to expenditure, it will be remembered that the original estimate was $254 million, and it will be seen from pages 15 and 16 of the Draft Estimates that it is likely that actual expenditure in 1957 will amount to about $242 million [only, I add in that word]. It should be noted, however, that this total includes a sum of $9 million in respect of compensation under the

Column: 2905

Malayanisation Scheme [as quoted by the hon. Member for Kampong Kapor]. If this sum is excluded - it is, I think, a fair charge on surplus funds since it will be recouped by savings on expatriation pay and passages over a period of years - what might be called normal' expenditure will amount to about $233 million [only] and there will probably be a small surplus of revenue over actual normal expenditure at the end of the year."

    Sir, according to the Financial Secretary, actual expenditure is only $233 million, that is excluding the $9 million for compensation under the Malayanisation scheme. Now if we add that $9 million, it comes up to only $242 million. Taking the $233 into consideration compared with what was originally estimated at $254 million, I now see that we are actually having a surplus of $2 million, rather than a deficit of $18.7 million as estimated by the Financial Secretary last year.

    Now, Sir, if we take the $9 million into consideration, we then actually have a deficit of only $7 million, and not, may I emphasise again, $18.7 million. Sir, if we compare this figure quoted by ,the Financial Secretary with the $7 million, I may call his figure a fictitious one. The budget for next year shows a substantial deficit of $35 million. Where can we get that money, Sir? I wonder whether the Financial Secretary will, when he comes before this House next year, say that the result will again be a surplus? May I quote what he has got to say, expecting that he may say that by next year, in col. 2830:

    "The position therefore is that the estimate of revenue is $242 million, the estimate of expenditure is $277 million, and we are faced with an estimated deficit of $35 million.

    The question is what would this deficit be in the event if no steps were taken to eliminate it. We know that, in the past, expenditure has invariably fallen short of the estimate and estimated deficits have turned into substantial surpluses."

    Very substantial surpluses, I may say. Sir, I would not certainly employ the Financial Secretary as the accountant of my firm if earlier he had predicted a deficit and then at the end of the year I found that I had a surplus. All these figures are just make-believe, just to misguide us -

Column: 2906



    Mr Speaker: Order. I think it is time I ought to pull up the hon. Member for using unparliamentary language. I think he has used the word "misguide". That word is unparliamentary.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I am sorry, Sir, I will stick to my original word "make-believe". These figures are just make-believe, to show us that there should be some form of taxation or increased taxation in order to meet this deficit of $35 million. Now it so happens that this year the Budget sittings happen to take place during election month. We will be having the City Council elections, and it is rather surprising that the Government has not got the courage to put up more taxation proposals, as they were expected to do. They have very carefully chosen only one item - one small item - and that is an increase of only 20 cents a gallon on petrol.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Very clever!

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Yes, very clever, and it is the contention of the Government that if it increases the duty on petrol, it will only soak the rich and will not affect the poor, because only the rich can afford to own cars. How can you expect poor people to own cars? But it is rather surprising, Sir, that we have so many vehicles on the road today. I wonder if every owner of a vehicle that is on the road is in fact a rich man. Does the Government know that most of the Government clerks also own cars? Are they rich people or are they working class people earning a few hundred dollars a month? I leave that to the Financial Secretary to answer.

    The Financial Secretary in his speech also said that this small increase of 20 cents a gallon on petrol will not affect the ordinary people at all. As I have said, it will only affect the rich. I will quote his speech again, Sir, in col. 2831.

    "This rate of $1 a gallon has been in force in the Federation since November of last year and its imposition is unlikely to cause any hardship in Singapore. It has caused none in the Federation."

Column: 2907



    Sir, every time the Government has something to say, "Oh, we must follow the Federation. We must fall in line with the Federation." Why? Why cannot the Federation for once follow us rather than that we follow the Federation? Let us set an example and let the Federation follow us for once. I quote again the Financial Secretary:

    "The new rate of duty will result in cars which do 20 miles to the gallon costing 1 cent a mile more to run. Those which do 30 miles to the gallon will cost 2/3rd of a cent a mile more to run, those doing 40 miles to the gallon, ½ a cent more, and so on. If 1,000 miles a month, or 30 miles a day, is taken as a fair average mileage for private cars in Singapore. cars doing 20 miles per gallon will cost $10 a month more to run, . . . These additional sums can be of no consequence to people who can afford to run cars for pleasure...".

    Now what about those who cannot afford to run cars for pleasure? What about the clerks working in Government offices, Sir? They do not own cars for the sake of running them for pleasure. They own cars so that they can go to work. I quote again from the Financial Secretary's speech:

    "Nor will the increase in duty be of much consequence to haulers. A round trip to Penang will cost about $10 more. I do not think that the increase in duty will affect consumption. The number of new cars, and the total number of cars registered, tend to increase each year and the consumption of petrol increases accordingly. I doubt if the increase will tend to make people use their cars less than they have done in the past."

    I will certainly try to take shortcuts or walk, if possible, so as to economise on petrol consumption. But if I do not, Sir, it is going to cost me $10 more a month. Is my employer going to pay me $10 more a month? I do not know where to get the extra $10. My income will be the same as it is now. Where can the Government expect me to get that extra $10? Beg, borrow or steal? Is the Government trying to encourage car owners to try and beg, borrow or steal to get the extra $10 a month? I leave it again to the Financial Secretary.

    In the 1956 Budget the petrol tax was increased by 5 cents. That was a very small figure. In the 1957 Budget the Government said they had to increase the petrol tax again by another

Column: 2908

7 cents, just to meet the deficit. Now in the 1958 Budget all of a sudden there is a jump of 20 cents. What will be the fate of the car owners then when the Financial Secretary puts up his 1959 Budget? Will the petrol tax go up by another 40 or 50 cents or even more? The Financial Secretary might bear in mind that a Member of the Assembly has suggested an increase of 50 cents.

    Sir, the Government has also increased the tax on heavy oil engine vehicles, and again the Financial Secretary has said that this will not affect anybody. Will that not affect the bus companies?
